arguments.claim: Accused deliberately made wrong entries in khasra for plots 170 and 74/1 entering Adit Pande as possessor, committing offence under s.218 IPC

anchor.surface_text: On July 31, 1951, Smt. Mahura Kuar filed the present complaint in the Court of the Judicial Magistrate at Ghazipur under s. 218 of the Indian Penal Code against the present appellant in which after reciting the various relevant facts she alleged that the accused who was a Patwari of the village had deliberately made wrong entries in regard to the plots Nos. 170 and 74/1 and in the remarks column had entered the name of Adit Pande as being in possession, and thus he had committed an offence under s. 218 of the Indian Penal Code.

arguments.claim: Accused made incorrect entries knowing them to be incorrect with intent to cause gain to Adit Pande and loss to Mahura Kuar

anchor.surface_text: The learned trial court found that the accused had made incorrect entries knowing them to be incorrect with intent to cause gain to Adit Pande and loss to Smt. Mahura Kuar. He, therefore, convicted the accused and sentenced him to one years rigorous imprisonment and a fine of Rs. 200 or in default 4 months rigorous imprisonment.

arguments.claim: Delivery of possession to Mahura Kuar proved by her statement and witnesses Gauri Shankar and Naresh; entries incorrect made to injure her

anchor.surface_text: The High Court confirmed the trial courts decision on the ground that the delivery of possession to the complainant Smt. Mahura Kuar was proved by the statements of the lady herself and of Gauri Shankar and Naresh Gadaria, who had supported the statement of Mahura Kuar and had deposed that Shubh Karan sapurdar had sown barley in one field and paddy in the other and that actual physical possession was delivered to her in April 1951.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: the ground that the delivery of possession to the companyplainant Smt. Mahura Kuar was proved by the statements of the lady herself and of Gauri Shan

arguments.court_reasoning: Possession finding noted but intent not sustained due to meagre evidence

arguments.claim: Patwari must make khasra entries based on actual facts by inquiry and field inspection per Rule 60 U.P. Land Records Manual

anchor.surface_text: Rule 60 of the U.P. Land Records Manual deals with the preparation of Khasras. The form of the khasra contains columns showing the name of the cultivator, the name of the sub-tenant or tenants and entries relating to crops etc. The rule requires that the entries shall be made in accordance with the actual facts and provides that the Patwari is responsible for all entries and he must satisfy himself of the facts by inquiry from the persons concerned as well as by field inspection and complete the khasra by April 30th.

arguments.court_reasoning: Used to assess correctness of entries during attachment period

arguments.claim: Prosecution must prove (1) accused knowingly framed incorrect record and (2) with intent or knowledge to cause loss or injury to public or Mahura Kuar

anchor.surface_text: For the purpose of this case, the prosecution had to prove- 1 that the accused knowingly framed the record in an incorrect manner and 2 that the accused did this with the intent to cause or with the knowledge that he would thereby cause loss or injury to the public or to Smt. Mahura Kuar.

arguments.claim: Accused knew of litigation and made incorrect entry, satisfying mens rea

anchor.surface_text: It is true that the High Court found that the accused knew of the litigation between Mahura Kuar and Adit Pande and in spite of this he had made an incorrect entry.

arguments.court_reasoning: Accepts knowledge of incorrectness but insufficient for intention under s.218

arguments.claim: No direct or sufficient circumstantial evidence of intent to cause loss or injury

anchor.surface_text: But in order to sustain the conviction it is not sufficient that the entries are incorrect, it is essential that the entry should have been made with the intention mentioned in s. 218 of the Indian Penal Code. Direct evidence proving the necessary intention is, in this case, lacking and the circumstantial evidence is too meagre to support any safe conclusion as to the intention with which the appellant made the entry complained of.

arguments.claim: Khasra entry for 1358F could cause loss to Mahura under s.16 U.P. Zamindari Abolition Act by deeming Adit hereditary tenant

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Mathur founded his case also on s. 16 of the U.P. Zamindari Abolition and Land Reforms Act, U.P. Act I of 1951 , which provided that a person, who was recorded as an occupant of the land for the year 1356 F and who, on the date mentioned in the section was in possession of the land, shall be deemed to be a hereditary tenant of the land.

arguments.court_reasoning: Entry is for 1358F not 1356F, irrelevant to s.16

arguments.claim: Incorrect entry in 1358F khasra could not cause loss as s.145 proceedings already concluded in Dec 1950 and possession ordered; entry made in March irrelevant

anchor.surface_text: The entry could not have been intended to create evidence -for being used against the complainant in the proceedings under s. 145 Criminal Procedure Code, because according to the evidence on the record the entries were made somewhere in March and this could not have helped Adit Pande, as the magistrate had already decided the proceedings under s. 145 Criminal Procedure Code in December 1950, and had ordered possession to be delivered to the complainant, and, therefore, this entry could not affect the result of the proceeding under s. 145 Criminal Procedure Code.

arguments.claim: Sapurdar Shubhkaran never obtained possession from Adit Pande

anchor.surface_text: His case was that the sapurdar, Shubhkaran, never got possession from Adit Pande. Shubhkaran was not a witness, may be for the reason already stated, and it was contended that in the absence of the testimony of Shubhkaran the case of the prosecution cannot be held to have been proved at least it is not free from doubt.

arguments.court_reasoning: Noted but courts below held for prosecution on possession

arguments.claim: Land attached under s.145, possession given to custodian Shubhkaran, not to Mahura till April 1951; she not in physical possession earlier

anchor.surface_text: Although the finding of the Magistrate in those proceedings was in favour of Smt. Mahura Kuar, the land in dispute had been attached and had been given for cultivation to Shubhkaran Chowkidar, and even according to the prosecution case the actual physical possession did not pass to Smt. Mahura Kuar till April 1951.

holdings.text: The prosecution had to prove that (1) the accused knowingly framed the record in an incorrect manner and (2) did so with intent to cause or knowledge of likely causing loss or injury to the public or Smt. Mahura Kuar.

anchor.surface_text: For the purpose,, of this case, the prosecution had to prove-  1 that the accused knowingly framed the record in an incorrect manner and  2 that the accused did this with the intent to cause or with the knowledge that he would thereby cause loss or injury to the public or to Smt. Mahura Kuar.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Elements of offence under s.218 IPC require proof of knowledge of incorrectness plus specific intent or knowledge of likely injury.

holdings.text: The accused knowingly framed an incorrect record as he knew of the litigation and s.145 order but made incorrect entry.

anchor.surface_text: It is true that the High Court found that the accused knew of the litigation between Mahura Kuar and Adit Pande and in spite of this he had made an incorrect entry.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Accepts High Court finding on knowledge of litigation and incorrectness of entries despite Magistrate's order.

holdings.text: Incorrect entries alone insufficient for conviction under s.218 IPC; must prove intention to cause loss or injury; direct evidence lacking and circumstantial evidence too meagre.

anchor.surface_text: But in order to sustain the convition it is not sufficient that the entries are incorrect, it is essential that the entry should have been made with the intention mentioned in s. 218 of the Indian Penal Code. Direct evidence proving the necessary intention is, in this case, lacking and the circumstantial evidence is too meagre to support any safe conclusion as to the intention with which the appellant made the entry complained of.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.218 requires mens rea beyond mere incorrectness; evidence inadequate to infer intent.

holdings.text: Khasra entry for 1358F could not cause loss in s.145 CrPC proceedings as they concluded in December 1950 before March 1951 entries.

anchor.surface_text: The entry could not have been intended to create evidence -for being used against the complainant 7O1 in the proceedings under s. 145 Criminal Procedure Code, because according to the evidence on the record the entries were made somewhere in March and this could not have helped Adit Pande, as the magistrate had already decided the proceedings under s. 145 Criminal Procedure Code in December 1950, and had ordered possession to be delivered to the complainant, and, therefore, this entry could not affect the result of the proceeding under s. 145 Criminal Procedure Code.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Timing of entries post-decision renders them irrelevant to concluded s.145 proceedings.

holdings.text: 1358F khasra entry irrelevant to s.16 UP Zamindari Abolition Act as it applies only to 1356F records.

anchor.surface_text: But the entry complained of is not for the year 1356 F but for the year 1358 F, and this entry would not have been of any avail to Adit Pande for the purposes of s. 16 of the Zamindari Abolition Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory deeming provision limited to specific year 1356F; 1358F entry cannot confer tenancy rights.

holdings.text: Prosecution failed to prove necessary criminal intention under s.218 IPC; no offence committed; appeal allowed, conviction set aside, accused acquitted.

anchor.surface_text: In the circumstances of the case it cannot be said that an offence under s. 218 has been committed by the appellant as in our opinion the prosecution has failed to prove the necessary criminal intention. In these circumstances, we would allow the appeal, ,set aside the order of conviction and acquit the accused.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative failure on mens rea element despite proof of incorrectness leads to acquittal.

holdings.text: Patwari entries in khasra must be based on actual facts verified by inquiry and field inspection per Rule 60 UP Land Records Manual.

anchor.surface_text: Rule 60 of the U.P. Land Records Manual deals with the preparation of Khasras. The form of the khasra contains columns showing the name of the cultivator, the name of the sub-tenant or tenants and entries relating to crops etc. The rule requires that the entries shall be made in accordance with the actual facts and provides that the Patwari is responsible for all entries and he must satisfy himself of the facts by inquiry from the persons concerned as well as by field inspection and complete the khasra by April 30th.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Restates duty under manual to assess correctness of entries.

anchor.surface_text: we would allow the appeal, ,set aside the order of companyviction and acquit the accused.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal allowed, order of conviction set aside, accused acquitted
directions: set aside the order of conviction
